div.p: Grace and peace from God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ. Amen.

First of all, I give thanks, most distinguished man, to the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has made and rendered me known and a friend to the heavenly one, especially to those through whom, as through intermediate instruments, He has partly revealed and partly more and more daily reveals the gospel of Christ, the eternally begotten Son, to His church spread throughout the entire world, as He wished to manifest Himself through the patriarchs, prophets, and apostles. Among these, you, most illustrious man, stand out to me as a chief figure and therefore to be especially honored among my friends. Indeed, I have often wished to see in person your church and well-established republic, in which, as Paul says, everything is done decently and in order. To visit which, I often encourage my listeners, as is known from your young men who hear me lecturing on Philipp's dialectics.

I have often wished, I say, but hitherto the stone and gout, my perpetual enemies, have hindered me, which I nevertheless willingly endure according to the spirit of patience imparted to me by the Almighty Lord, and I recognize the paternal mind towards me, a miserable sinner, of the Almighty, speaking in human terms, who tempts no one beyond what we can bear.

Since therefore it is not permitted to see your kindnesses in person with bodily sight, yet in the meantime I see and hear you with my mind, while I diligently and carefully read your writings, especially yours, most humane man. For what I have been able to have so far on the New Testament (I have, moreover, your excellency's commentaries on the entire New Testament, to which was recently added a splendid exposition of the Apocalypse of the apostle and evangelist John), in these I take delight and seek rest for my soul.
